langUsage.language: French as written in the 17th century

correspDesc.note: La Valette sends an update on preparations for battle and thanks the cardinal for naming him Sargent of Battle. Spanish troops have arrived in the Piedmont and Christine expects military support from France. Father Monod remains at Montmelian.

editorialDecl.p: The dictionaries used to check spellings and confirm understanding of words in these transcriptions are the Dictionnaire de l'Académie française of 1694 and Jean Nicot's Thresor de la langue françoyse, tant ancienne que moderne of 1606, both accessed through the Dictionnaires d'autrefois database of the University of Chicago ARTFL Project. In addition to these two resources, anyone attempting to read these letters who is not familiar with the standard ways that 17th century French differs from modern French might find this short guide by Thomas Luckett at Portland State University helpful: Reading Old Regime French.

Essential as these resources are to deciphering the letters in this archive, they also do reveal the extent to which orthography, letter formation, and punctuation were not yet standardized in seventeenth century France. Spelling was phonetic and varied, even within a single document and even for proper nouns. The letters "f" and "s," "p" and "q," "r" and "t" were often indistinguishable, making consideration of the context of the surrounding words essential. Commas were nearly non-existant, and full-stop punctuation was often omitted, especially at the ends of lines. The informality and assumed privacy of the epistolary form may have only encouraged these ambiguities and variations.

The archival letters in this collection are either hand-written documents in manuscript or are letters transcribed and printed in the seventeenth century. In the modern transcriptions of the print letters, elements that have more to do with page design than the original (lost) manuscript letters have not been retained. These include line breaks, soft end-of-line hyphens, the all-caps presentation of opening and closing salutations, running heads, letter titles, page numbers, and page signatures. In the transcriptions of manuscript letters, design elements have been retained to the extent possible, to facilitate the coordinated reading of facsimile and transcription. (It should be noted that, for all transcriptions, a hyphenated word will not return in a search of the the word as normally spelled.)
In all of the transcriptions, of both early modern print and manuscript letters, original spelling and punctuation have been retained, with the following exceptions for correction and normalization:

correction.p: Correction. In the semi-diplomatic view, two types of correction have been made silently: First, known abbreviations have been expanded, as with Mr./Monsieur, S.M./Sa Majesté, and V.E./Vostre Eminence. Second, in words that have been connected to a preceding article or pronoun, apostrophes have been added, as with daffection/d'affection, nest/n'est, and mescrire/m'escrire.

Any spellings that that are evidnet errors, in that they would lead to a mispronounciation of a known word, are highlighted in the transcription. Hovering over the highlighted word will prompt display of the corrected spelling.

Any words that are completely illegible are indicated with a bracked question mark. Words that are simply not recognizable as words have been transcribed to the extent possible and are immediately followed by question mark.

normalization.p: Normalization. In 17th century paleography and typography, "u" and "v" were two forms of the same letter, which could serve as either a vowel or a consonant. Usually the v-form was used initially, while the u-form was used medially. Similarly, the letter "j" was usually represented by the "i," both at the beginning and in the middle of words.

In this archive, the user may choose to view either a "semi-diplomatic" transcription, which reproduces the u, v, i, and j just as they were written in the source text, or a "normalized" transcription, which converts each letter to its appropriate noun or verb form.

person.note: Keeper of the Seals (Garde des sceaux) of France from 1624 to 1635.
The favorite and most trusted advisor of Christine of France during her regency.
Soldier and governor of Languedoc from 1633 to 1644. He was named Marshall of France in 1637 after his victory at the Battle of Leucate.
Lawyer, councillor of state, and inspector of French forces under Richelieu.
A French general instrumental in restoring Catholicism in the south-western provinces of Languedoc and Guyenne. He was made a duke and ambassador to Poland by Louis XIV.
A writer of popular epistolary essays and founding member of the Académie française.

person.persName: Bernard de Nogaret de La Valette, 2e duc d’Épernon
person.note: French general and brother of Henri de Nogaret, duc de Candalle (d. 1639), and Louis de Nogaret, Cardinal de La Valette. He became duc d’Épernon on his father’s death in 1642.
First president of the parliament of Toulouse, from 1632 until at least 1649. In 1632 he helped put down the rebellion of Henri II de Montmorency.
Wife of Claude Bouthillier, comte de Chavigny. She was entrusted with the education of Richelieu’s orphaned niece (Tapié, p. 394).
Catholic priest and pamphleteer in the service of Marie de Medici. In 1633 he was involved in a failed attempt to assassinate Cardinal Richelieu (Blanchard, p.151; Knecht, p. 55).
Charles I reigned from 1625 until his execution in 1649. In the same year he ascended the throne, he married Henrietta Maria of France, sister of Louis XIII.

Second son of Victor Amadeus I, duke of Savoy, and Christine of France. His inheritance of the duchy at the age of 4 on the death of his brother Francis Hyacinth was challenged by his uncles Thomas, prince of Carignano, and Maurice, prince of Savoy.

person.persName: Gaspard III de Coligny, marquis de Chatillon
person.note: A Huguenot general known for his loyalty to Louis XIII, named Marshall of France in 1622.

Appointed secretary of state by Richelieu in 1628 and superintendant of finances in 1632, offices he held until the death of Louis XIII in 1643. Chavigny also lead many diplomatic missions, sometimes accompanied by Père Joseph.

person.persName: Christine, duchess consort of Victor Amadeus I, duke of Savoy
person.note: Sister of Louis XIII and wife of Victor Amadeus I, duke of Savoy. At the duke’s death in 1637 she became regent, first in the name of her son Francis Hyacinth (d. 1638), then in the name of her second son, Charles-Emmanuel II. Her regency was challenged by her brothers-in-law Thomas, prince of Carignano, and Maurice, prince of Savoy, in the Piedmontese Civil War.
Advisor to Richelieu and member of a banking family from Lucca.

person.persName: Jean-Louis de Nogaret de La Valette, 1e duc d’Épernon
person.note: First duc d’Épernon and father of Henri (d. 1639), Bernard (2e duc d’Épernon), and Louis, Cardinal de La Valette.
Vice-admiral instrumental in putting down a Huguenot rebellion in La Rochelle in 1622, named Marshall of France in 1627.

Former page of Louis XIII sent on a diplomatic mission to Holland at the age of 19. His diplomatic and military service would continue into the reign of Louis XIV, who would name him Marshall of France in 1675.

person.persName: Francois Annibal de Coeuvres, maréchal d’Estrées
person.note: Peer of France named Marshal of France in 1626. After his military career he entered diplomacy, serving as French envoy to Rome from 1636 to 1648.

person.persName: Ferdinando II de Medici, granduca di Toscana
person.note: Grand-Duke of Tuscany from 1621 to 1670; friend and protector of Galileo Galilei.
Pope from 1621 to 1623. He called Richelieu the “rampart of Catholic religion and the scourge of heretics” and elevated him to cardinal in 1622 (Blanchard, p. 116).
Eldest son of the first duc d’Épernon, and brother of Bernard and Louis, Cardinal de La Valette. On Henri’s death in 1639, his brother Bernard would inherit the title.

person.persName: Henrietta Maria, queen consort of Charles I, king of England
person.note: Sister of Louis XIII, king of France. Her marriage to Charles I was negotiated by Richelieu, who at the time was an equal member of the king’s council. The negotiation is regarded as Richelieu’s first diplomatic success (Levi, p. 81).
Scottish soldier of fortune appointed commander of the Scots Brigade by Cardinal de La Valette in 1636. He was killed in Lorraine in 1637 while serving under Chatillon.

person.persName: Francois de l’Hospital, comte du Hallier
person.note: Youngest son in an aristocratic family who renounced the religious life to pursue a military career at the age of 15. He would represent Louis XIII at the signing of the articles of capitulation ending the seige of La Rochelle in 1628 and serve in many campaigns in the Thirty Years’ War.

person.persName: François Leclerc du Tremblay, père Joseph
person.note: French Capuchin friar, friend and advisor to Richelieu, unofficial negotiator with German states, and the original “eminence grise.” His willingness to ally France with Protestant powers against Catholic Spain prevented his elevation to cardinal, despite Richelieu’s efforts (Blanchard, pp. 125 and 270, n. 21).

person.persName: Diego Felipe de Guzmàn, marquis de Leganès
person.note: Cousin of the Count of Olivares, first minister to Philip IV of Spain and, as of 1635, captain general and governor of the Duchy of Milan. He was active in the Piedmontese Civil War, 1639–41.

person.persName: François de Bonne, duc de Lesdiguières
person.note: Leader of the Huguenot resistance in Dauphiné, he served under the future Henry IV from the 1580s and would be named Marshall of France by that king in 1609. He was loyal to Louis XIII and, after converting to Catholicism in 1622, was named constable of France.

The second Bourbon king, Louis ascended the throne at the assassination of his father Henry IV in 1610 and in 1617 forcibly took power from his mother the regent, Marie de Medici. Considered a suspicious and insecure ruler, Louis relied on a succession of competing advisors and favorites, most notably Richelieu.

Grand Falconer of France and companion of Louis during the regency, he convinced the young king to end the regency in a palace coup in 1617. Named constable of France in 1621, he died of a fever that same year while laying seige to the Huguenot town of Montauban.

person.persName: Maria Anna, empress consort of Ferdinand III, Holy Roman Emperor
person.note: Infanta of Spain, she married the Austrian Hapsburg Ferdinand Ernest, future Holy Roman Emperor, in 1626. Richelieu opposed this strengthening of the alliance between the Spanish and Austrian branches of the Hapsburg family (Tapié, p. 296).

person.persName: Marie de’Medici, queen consort of Henry IV, king of France
person.note: Second wife of Henry IV, crowned queen of France the day before the king’s assassination in 1610. In 1617 she was forced from power in a palace coup and expelled to Blois. Though she reconciled with Louis and returned to court in 1621, her attempt to end Richelieu’s influence in 1630 on the “Day of the Dupes” would result in her permanent exile.

person.persName: Maurice, prince of Savoy and cardinal of Vercelli
person.note: Brother of Victor Amadeus I, duke of Savoy. On the death of the duke in 1637, his surviving brothers Maurice and Thomas, prince of Carignano, attempted to take the regency from Christine of France, inciting the Piedmontese Civil War.
Jesuit priest and Spanish sympathizer at the court of Christine, duchess of Savoy. His arrest and removal to Montmélian by the French aroused Christine’s anger against Richelieu (Tapié, p. 390).

person.persName: Hercule de Rohan, duc de Montbazon
person.note: Peer of France who served Henry III and Henry IV; he was riding in the carriage when Henry IV was assassinated in 1610. His daughter Marie would become the infamous Madame de Chevreuse, conspirator in the courts of Louis XIII and Louis XIV.

Godson of Henri IV, governor of Languedoc, and a leading figure at the court of Louis XIII. As Grand Admiral and Marshall of France he put down several Huguenot rebellions and won victories against Spain in the Piedmont. In 1632 he joined Gaston d’Orleans, Louis’ brother, in a failed attempt remove Cardinal Richelieu from power. Ignoring pleas for mercy throughout France, Richelieu executed Montmorency as an example to other members of his class.

person.persName: François Sublet de Noyers, Baron de Dangu
person.note: Secretary of State, member of the king’s council, and loyal creature of Cardinal Richelieu.
Son of Maximilien de Béthune, duc de Sully.

person.persName: Philippe de Clerembault, comte de Palluau
person.note: Officer of noble birth who would rise from captain of a company of light horsemen in the 1630s to Marshall of France by 1653.
Hapsburg king who reigned from 1621 to 1640 and allied with the Austrian Hapsburgs against France in the Thirty Years’ War, 1618–48.

person.persName: Antoine de L’Age, Duc de Puylaurens
person.note: Confidant and advisor to Gaston, duc d’Orleans, Louis XIII’s brother. Puylaurens was arrested in 1635 for aiding Gaston’s escape from France in the aftermath of a failed attempt to remove Richelieu from power, and for facilitating the politically unfavorable marriage of Gaston to Marguerite of Lorraine. Puylaurens died at Vincennes after seven months of imprisonment (Blanchard, pp. 151–53).

person.persName: Armand-Jean du Plessis, cardinal duc de Richelieu

person.note: Member of an aristocratic Savoyard family.

person.persName: Maximilien de Béthune, duc de Sully
person.note: Protestant favorite of Henry IV, Chief minister and from 1589, and superintendent of finances from 1600 until Henry’s assassination in 1610. Sully helped to bring financial stability to France after the wars of religion, put down Huguenot rebellions, encouraged agriculture, and rebuilt infrastructure.

person.persName: Pons de Lauzières, marquis de Thémines
person.note: Member of the court of Henry IV and supporter of Marie de’Medici during the regency, named Marshall of France in 1616. In 1619 Thémines’ son Antoine killed Henri du Plessis, the older brother of the future Cardinal Richelieu, in a duel.

Brother of Victor Amadeus I, duke of Savoy. On the death of the duke in 1637, Thomas and his brother Maurice, prince of Savoy, attempted to take the regency from Christine of France, inciting the Piedmontese Civil War.

person.persName: Henri de la Tour d’Auvergne, vicomte de Turenne
person.note: French military general instrumental in defeating the forces of Prince Tommaso in the Piedmontese Civil War. He was named Marshal of France in 1643 and later to Marshal General.
Pope from 6 August 1623 to 29 July 1644.

person.persName: Louis de Nogaret, cardinal de La Valette
person.note: Cardinal and lieutenant general in the French army, brother of Henri de Nogaret, duc de Candalle and Bernard de Nogaret, duc d’Épernon as of 1642.

person.persName: Victor Amadeus I, duke of Savoy
Victor Amadeus I, duke of Savoy
person.note: Husband of Christine of France. His death in 1637 and the death of his eldest son, Francis Hyacinth, in 1639 lead to the Piedmontese Civil War, as the regency of Christine was challenged by the duke’s brothers, Thomas, prince of Carignano and Maurice, prince of Savoy.

place.placeName: Château de la Grange des Prés
Château de la Grange des Prés
place.note: Estate of the Dukes of Montmorency, north of Pézenas in Languedoc-Roussillon, Southern France. In July of 1629 Henri II Montmorency hosted Richelieu at the château.

Huguenot stronghold on the western coast of France; site of a rebellions in 1622 and 1625 that subsequently received military support from England. In 1627 Richelieu organized a blockade; La Rochelle surrendured 14 months later.
Commune north of Spain on the Mediterranean coast of France.
Commune in the Bourgogne region of France.
City in south-central France.
City in Lorraine, in north-eastern France near Luxembourg.
Village in the Asti region of Piedmont, about 45 km east of Turin.
Part of the Piedmont gained by Savoy in the War of the Mantuan Succession, 1628–31.

Commune in Languedoc, about 15 km from Toulouse.
Town in Savoy about 50 km from Turin that came under French control in 1631.
Commune in the Île-de-France region of north-central France.
Commune in Brittany about 30 km from the coast.
Commune located half-way between Louis XIII’s primary residence at Saint-Germain-en-Laye and Paris. Richelieu’s preferred residence from 1633 until his death in 1642 was at Rueil.
Commune in the Loire Valley in western France.
Royal palace about 12 km outside of Paris and a prinicpal residence of Louis XIII.
City in the Piedmont and capital of the Duchy of Savoy in the 16th and 17th centuries.

titlePart.title: Cardinal de La Valette to Cardinal Richelieu, n.d.

body.p:
I J ’ay veu par la Lettre[1] This letter is reproduced in Avenel vol. 6, pp. 275–77). que vostre Eminence m’a fait l’honneur de m’écrire du vingt-quatriéme Ianuier Janvier, les ordres que vous auez avez donnez, tant pour le payement
des garnisons de Cazal & de Pignerol, durant les trois premiers mois de ceste année, que pour les subsistances de l’armée.
Les cent septante cinq mil liures livres destinez pour les garnisons se reçoiuent reçoivent de iour jour à autre, & ie je croy qu’il n’y aura point de manquement.

Des cent mil-francs que Monsieur de Lauson doit enuoyer envoyer , les cinquante mil sont arriuez arrivez , le reste doit estre icy dans sept ou huict iours jours à ce qu’on me mande de Lion. De sorte, Monseigneur, que c’est vn un argent asseuré. Ie Je croy aussi que les autres deux cent mil-francs nous seront bien-tost enuoyez envoyez , ainsi que le sieur Tiebault de Lyon me le promet, & si les 350000. liures livres que V. Eminence me mande qu’elle nous enuoyera envoyera dans ce mois, & celuy de Mars, arriuent arrivent elle se peut asseurer que nos Troupes seront en tres-bon estat,ce qui me semble necessaire, c’est que ie je sçache ponctuellement comme il vous plaist de me le mander, le fonds dont nous pouuons pouvons faire estat asseuré, parce que selon cela ie je
trouue trouve moyen de faire aduancer advancer le payement en donnant l’interest à ceux qui le prestent.

Ie Je fais maintenant partir ce Courrier pour dire à Vostre Eminence comme i j ’ay eu des nouuelles nouvelles des recreuës du Languedoc par Monsieur de Castelan, vous verrez, s’il vous plaist, ce qu’il m’en mande par sa Lettre, afin de commander qu’on y remedie, car il faut que toutes les recreuës & la Caualerie Cavalerie soyent en Piedmont dés le dix ou quinziéme d’ Auril Avril , afin que nous puissions entrer dans l’Estat de Milan dans le premier de May, & si Vostre Eminence me mande ce qu’elle desire que j’entreprenne, ie je me disposeray de bonne heure à essayer de l’executer.

Outre les deux Aydes de Camp que i j ’ay enuoyez envoyez en Lyonnois & en Dauphiné, j’en dépesche encore vn un autre en Languedoc, pour sçauoir sçavoir en quel estat sont les recreuës, on ne sçauroit trop presser les Officiers, car ils sont lents par eux-mesmes.

I J ’ecry à tous ceux qui commandent le corps qui soyent bien armez, que leurs mousquets soyent d’ vne une once de balée, & leurs picques de quatorze à quinze pieds, outre le magazin qu’il vous plaist que nous ayons de 5000. mousquets, & de 5000. picques, si on veut enuoyer envoyer les armes, i j ’en seray bien-aise, sinon ie je les feray faire, mais il faut que i j ’aye promptement vne une resolution, car il faut deux mois de temps à les faire faire. Enfin, Monseigneur, ie je vous supplie tres-humblement de croire que ie je n’espargneray rien pour le seruice service du Roy, selon vos commandemens, la principale chose est de presser nos recreuës--car ie je crains que les Officiers ne passent pas assez diligemment, mon intention est de faire passer toutes les Troupes en quinze iours jours , afin de bien commencer la Campagne.
Ie Je souhaitte que Monsieur de Turenne vienne le plutost qu’il se pourra, il ne se peut rien adjouster à la bonté que vous auez avez pour luy, & pour tous ceux qui seruent servent avec affection.

L’honneur que vous me faites de me donner vn un Sergent de Bataille, est vne une affection extraordinaire, ce qui m’a obligé à le demander, à esté le desir de seruir servir & d’établir quelque ordre dans ceste armée, laquelle en a grand besoin, mais ie je ne voudrois pas pour quoy que ce soit au monde, supplier vostre Eminence de quelque chose qu’elle ne jugeât pas raisonnable, & quand ie je le fais c’est en me soûmettant entierement à vous, à qui ie je dois toute sorte de respect & d’obeyssance.

Monsieur de Paluau vous aura dit ce qui s’est passé en l’affaire du Pere Monot, vous connoissez mieux que moy l’esprit de Madame, elle croit que le Roy, & vous, Monseigneur, luy auez avez des obligations infinies de ce qu’elle a arresté le Pere Monot,
ie je luy dis encor hier au soir mon opinion sur ceste affaire, & sur la necessité qu’elle a de la protection du Roy, & de la vostre.

Elle a des aduis advis que les Espagnols doiuent doivent entrer dans le Piedmont, ce qui luy donne l’alarme extrémement, mais lors que nos Troupes seront passées, ie je croy que nous la garentirons de la force, non pas de la traihison, nous auons avons esté aduerty adverty d’ vne une qui se trouuoit trouvoit sur le Chenchio par le moyen du Cardinal de Sauoye Savoye
, on est apres à découurir ceux qui y ont trempé, ie je fay ce que ie je puis pour la presser à gouuerner gouverner
auec avec quelque fermeté, mais il est difficile à la faire resoudre à arrester ceux mesmes de qui elle a quelques soupçons assez bien fondez, elle a eu aduis advis certain que le Cardinal de Sauoye Savoye a fait acheter des poisons fort subtils à Gennes, ce qui luy donne de grandes inquietudes, & ie je croy que ce n’est pas sans raison.

Aussi-tost que nous aurons aduis advis qu’on aura accepté les Lettres d’échange que nous auons avons tirées pour la fortification du Pont d’Esture, nous y ferons trauailler, j’ enuoyeray envoyeray dans deux iours jours à V. Eminence, le marché qu’en a fait le sieur Collebert, lequel entend fort bien ces choses-là, ie je ne manquery pas de donner aduis advis à Vostre Eminence de tout ce qui se passera, & ne perdray iamais jamais occasion de luy témoigner par mon seruice service tres-humble que ie je suis auec avec la fidelité & la reconnoissance sance que ie dois,

postscript.p: Ie Je vous enuoye envoye l’estat de la dépense qui seroit necessaire pour la fortification des places de Monferrat durant toute l’année fait par le sieur de Colbert, il en enuoye envoye le menu à Monsieur de Noyers.
I J ’enuoye à Monsieur de Noyers la Lettre de Monsieur de Castelan, pour éuiter éviter la peine à Vostre Eminence de la lire.
